LETTERS TO THE EDITOR

Benzodiazepine Reduction
and a Generalized
Tonic-Clonic Seizure With
Therapeutic Benefit in
Catatonia Associated With
Autism Spectrum Disorder

Dr. Jonathan P Rogers, University College London, 6th floor, Maple House, 149 Tottenham Court Road, Bloomsbury, London, W1T 7NF, GB
literature - Parry S, Raheem A, Williams E, Rogers JP. Benzodiazepine Reduction and a Generalized Tonic-Clonic Seizure With Therapeutic Benefit in Catatonia Associated With Autism Spectrum Disorder. Journal of ECT. 2022;38(3):218-9. DOI: 10.1097/YCT.0000000000000835.

To the Editor:
We describe improvement in catatonia
after a seizure related to benzodiazepine withdrawal. A 21-year-old woman with
a history of preterm birth, patent ductus
arteriosus, neonatal intraventricular hemorrhage, chronic compensated hydrocephalus,
prediabetes mellitus, polycystic ovarian syndrome, mild intellectual disability, and
autism spectrum disorder was referred to
outpatient mental health services. Her only
previous seizure had been age 15 years,
while taking sertraline and quetiapine and
she was not subsequently on anticonvulsants.
She had previously been treated since the age
of 13 years for social withdrawal, poor sleep,
reduced appetite, and hearing voices after a
suspected bullying incident on a school trip,
which gradually deteriorated, characterized
by poor occupational function, lack of motivation, and mutism. Previous trials of sertraline, quetiapine, risperidone, and aripiprazole
were unsuccessful.
After transition to adult mental health
services at the age of 18 years, she was
reassessed, and it was observed that she
presented with features of catatonia, including mutism, staring, stereotypy, waxy
flexibility, and tachycardia with a heart rate
ranging from 135 to 145 per minute during
clinical reviews, meeting Diagnostic and
Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (Fifth
Edition) criteria for catatonic disorder not otherwise specified. Using the Bush Francis Catatonia Rating Scale, she scored 7 of 14 on the
screening instrument and 16 of 69 for severity. She was treated for catatonia in autism
with oral lorazepam (off-label use) with the
intention of using electroconvulsive therapy
(ECT) if this was unsuccessful. As an outpatient, lorazepam was titrated slowly for
10 months to a total daily dose of 16 mg in divided doses without any improvement, so a
decision was made to restart sertraline at
50 mg and to wean down the benzodiazepine
dose by switching to diazepam because of its
longer half-life. Lorazepam (16 mg) was converted to 50 mg of diazepam (off-label), and
sertraline was increased to 100 mg.

Three days after the switch from lorazepam to diazepam, the patient had a generalized tonic-clonic seizure at home lasting
7 minutes. She was transferred to the emergency department, where she had a further
seizure. There was evidence of a mild inflammatory response with a white blood
cell count of 12.5  109/L, C-reactive protein of 28 mg/L, platelets of 454  109/L,
and initial lactate of 8.0 mmol/L, which
normalized on repeat. No cause of seizure
was identified, and no evidence of other
symptoms of benzodiazepine withdrawal
was noted. She had no further seizures after
discharge.
After the seizure, the dose of diazepam was held at 50 mg for 3 weeks before
restarting the reducing regimen. For the
first 2 days after the seizures, she was
postictal and drowsy. However, by day
7, the patient's presentation changed, and
she was noted to become substantially more
communicative. She was described as chatty
and asked questions about her diagnosis and
her medication for the first time in years.
In the next few months, as diazepam was
gradually reduced, the improvement in
symptoms was sustained. She continued
to communicate more, both verbally and
by using messages on her mobile. Because
of coronavirus disease 2019 restrictions,
the further reduction in diazepam has been
managed in the community, with telephone
consultations only, hitherto uneventfully, so
monitoring with the Bush Francis Catatonia
Rating Scale has not been possible. She was
reviewed by cardiology 3 months after the
seizure because of persistent tachycardia.
By this time, the tachycardia had improved
to 102 per minute, which was thought to
be due to iron deficiency anemia. Her improvement does not seem to have been
sustained in the long term.
To our knowledge, this is the first report of improvement of catatonia after a
seizure in the context of benzodiazepine
reduction. Benzodiazepine equivalences
are not universally agreed, but 50 mg of
diazepam may be a lower dose than 16 mg
of lorazepam,1 which could have been a factor, in addition to her underlying vulnerabilities. Autism spectrum disorder is associated
with an increased propensity to seizures.2
Furthermore, the increase in sertraline from
50 mg to 100 mg may have been a precipitating factor, as her only previous seizure
also occurred when she was treated with
sertraline. Finally, given the mild inflammatory response noted in the emergency
department, an infection may have been a
contributing factor.

There are a number of possible triggers
for the improvement in the patient's symptoms.
First, the high dose of lorazepam may
have had a sedative effect, which improved
after a dose reduction. This seems unlikely,
given that the patient had these symptoms
before lorazepam treatment and benzodiazepines do not tend to cause features such as
waxy flexibility, stereotypy, and tachycardia.
Second, sertraline may have treated an
underlying anxiety or depressive illness.
Again, this seems improbable because sertraline previously had little effect and the
dramatic improvement occurred within days
of increasing the dose.
Third, we suggest that the most likely
reason for the patient's improvement is that
the seizure was therapeutic for the catatonic
state. Benzodiazepine withdrawal is known
to sometimes precipitate catatonia.3 However, ECT is a recommended and evidencebased treatment for catatonia. Before the
use of ECT, pharmacological provocation
of seizures using a variety of agents had
been used as a treatment of catatonia.4 It
is therefore plausible that a seizure induced
by withdrawal of a medication might be
equally effective.
Treatment of catatonia in autism is
supported only by case reports and case
series, which suggest that benzodiazepines
and ECT should be used.5 In this case, given
that lorazepam was unsuccessful, ECTwould
have been an appropriate treatment and could
have been considered given that her hydrocephalus was stable.
This report supports the notion that
ECT should be considered early as a potential therapeutic modality in catatonia
in autism even when there is no immediate
risk to life. It also provides a caution about
gradual titration of benzodiazepines in catatonia, as it can cause tolerance and may
risk withdrawal seizures, especially in individuals with risk factors for seizures. Finally,
this case illustrates a complex relationship between seizures and catatonia, because catatonia can be a manifestation of nonconvulsive
status epilepticus.
A number of features of this case may
limit the applicability to many patients with
catatonia and autism, given her complex
medical history. However, it illustrates an
important paradoxical response to a reduction in benzodiazepine dose.
Sarah Parry
South London and Maudsley NHS
Foundation Trust
London, UK

Rapid Resolution of
Prolonged BenzodiazepineRefractory Catatonia With
Electroconvulsive Therapy in
an Adolescent Patient
A Case Report
To the Editor:
atatonia is a debilitating and underdiagnosed syndrome characterized by a

C

range of motor and behavioral disturbances.1
Among pediatric patients, catatonia is often
secondary to genetic or developmental conditions,2 although it also co-occurs with numerous psychiatric conditions. Although there is
little prospective research on the treatment of
catatonia, benzodiazepines are the mainstay
of treatment, with retrospective data in child
and adolescent patients showing a 65% response rate to benzodiazepine treatment.3
In chronic catatonia, however, the role of
benzodiazepines is less clear, with the only
prospective trial of lorazepam in that setting demonstrating no benefit.4 Numerous
case reports have demonstrated the effectiveness of electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) in
the treatment of medication-refractory acute
catatonia. For instance, 8 of 9 adult catatonic
patients—including 5 who did not respond to
intravenous (IV) amobarbital—had a favorable response to ECT.5 The use of ECT in
prolonged catatonia and in refractory symptoms in young patients is less discussed.
Here, we present a case of benzodiazepinerefractory catatonia of 4 months duration in
an adolescent patient who rapidly resolved
with ECT treatment.
The patient was a 16-year-old adolescent boy who before presentation was typically developing, attending regular high school
classes and with no chronic medical or psychiatric conditions. He took no medications
and had no family history of psychiatric illness. Per family, the patient had the acute
onset of behavioral changes, including decreased speech, behavioral isolation, and
slowed movements. Approximately 10 days
after symptom onset, the patient stopped
eating or drinking and had minimal speech;
the family then brought him to an outside
emergency department. The patient's initial
examination was notable for mutism, staring,
slowed gait, and stereotyped movements. His
tone was noted to be normal, although the
patient did not cooperate with the motor examination. Brain magnetic resonance imaging without the administration of IV contrast
and 8-hour electroencephalography recording
were normal, as were laboratory findings
including a serum autoimmune panel, basic
metabolic panel, vitamin D, rapid plasma
reagin, and HIV screening. The diagnosis
of catatonia was made with an initial BushFrancis Catatonia Rating Scale (BFCRS)
of 18. The patient was admitted to the pediatrics service of the outside hospital where
he was started on lorazepam 2 mg IV 3
times daily without significant response.
Over the following month, he remained
on the pediatrics floor and was followed
by consult liaison psychiatry, with multiple medication trials including olanzapine
up to 2.5 mg twice daily (resulting in increased
catatonic features and urinary incontinence),
aripiprazole 2 mg, and escitalopram 10 mg

for empiric treatment of a possible depressive episode. Given ongoing minimal intake by mouth (PO), the patient was started
on enteral feeding via a nasogastric tube.
On hospital day 41, he was transferred
to the pediatric medical-psychiatric unit at
the outside hospital, where lorazepam was
increased to a dose of 6 mg PO 3 times
daily with some improvement in catatonic
features, but he continued to demonstrate
withdrawal, staring, stereotypies, and minimal PO intake requiring ongoing nasogastric tube feeds. He began to display some
symptoms of self-dialoguing and paranoia,
which were thought consistent with catatonic schizophrenia, so he was trialed on a
series of antipsychotic medications (aripiprazole up to 5 mg daily; risperidone up to
6 mg daily; haloperidol up to 20 mg daily)
without significant response.
Given lack of therapeutic improvement,
ECT consultation from our hospital was
sought on hospital day 118, and the patient
was deemed an appropriate candidate for
ECT. He was transferred to the pediatrics
floor of our hospital on day 129, where
BFCRS was 15; ECT was initiated the following day. Because of the severity of illness,
no dose titration was conducted, and ECT
was started with bilateral electrode placement (Mecta Spectrum 5000Q: pulse width
0.5 ms, frequency 40 Hz, duration 6 seconds,
current 800 mA, 192 mC) with methohexital
anesthesia and succinylcholine muscle relaxant. After 2 ECT treatments, the BFCRS was
reduced to 8, and after his third treatment (bilateral, 0.5 ms, 40 Hz, 8 seconds, 256 mC),
he began eating spontaneously (BFCRS 7).
As the patient's catatonia began to lyse,
there was the emergence of greater psychotic
symptoms for which quetiapine was initiated,
with ultimate cross-taper to aripiprazole. His
catatonia continued to improve with ECT,
with the BFCRS reduced to 2 after 7 treatments.
He was ultimately discharged after 17 ECT
treatments on hospital day 167 (38 days after
transfer). Catatonia was in full remission at that
time, and discharge medications were aripiprazole 15 mg daily, clonazepam 2 mg twice
daily, and memantine 10 mg twice daily.
This case highlights the critical role of
timely access to ECT in the treatment of
pediatric catatonia. This patient's catatonia
was recognized rapidly, but despite prompt
treatment with lorazepam, his catatonic symptoms did not improve, as is the case for 35%
of pediatric catatonia patients.3 It is possible
that a higher lorazepam dose or alternative
catatonia pharmacotherapy (eg, glutamatergic
agents) may have been helpful if attempted
earlier. There is clearly a need for better pharmacotherapy options for pediatric catatonia,
as in this case numerous medication trials
did not result in improvement: indeed, the
patient's BFCRS did not change substantially
